name: gt
description: Build display tables from tabular data with an easy-to-use set of functions using the R package called gt. With its progressive approach, we can construct display tables with a cohesive set of table parts. Table values can be formatted using any of the included formatting functions. Footnotes and cell styles can be  precisely added through a location targeting system. The way in which gt handles things for you means that you don't often have to worry about the fine details.
description_good_justification: The page at https://gt.rstudio.com gives an overview of the package, which problems the software is good at addressing, and several introductory-level examples.
interact_justification: The project website provides information on all of this. In the 'Installation' section (https://gt.rstudio.com/#installation), instructions are provided on how to install the CRAN version of the package and the in-development version. The final sentence invites users to report bugs, ask questions about usage, and share ideas for new features in the GitHub Issues page (link provided in sentence).
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: The pull request template at https://github.com/rstudio/gt/blob/master/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md has a checklist of requirements for an acceptable contribution.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/rstudio/gt/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: MIT attribution: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rstudio/gt/master/LICENSE.md. The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license his approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI). The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: There is full documentation for the package functions and an introductory article available in the project website (https://gt.rstudio.com/). The Reference section of the project website (https://gt.rstudio.com/reference/index.html) arranges the package functions into families with descriptions of each function family. Additionally, help for each function can be obtained by using `help(<function name>)` in the R console.
documentation_interface_justification: The manual available at (https://gt.rstudio.com/ goes into detail about the interface, and the help files at https://github.com/rstudio/gt/tree/main/man document and demonstrate every exported function in full detail. The `man` folder is the standard way to document exported functions and data objects in an R package.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The GitHub releases at https://github.com/rstudio/gt/releases include multiple interim development releases.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: The gt package follows the versioning guide at http://r-pkgs.had.co.nz/release.html#release-version, the community accepted variant of semantic versioning for R packages.
version_tags_justification: All releases (viewable at https://github.com/rstudio/gt/releases) have a git/GitHub tag.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/rstudio/gt/blob/master/NEWS.md>.
report_responses_justification: The Issue tracker contains all bug reports: https://github.com/rstudio/gt/issues
enhancement_responses_justification: The issue tracker contains all feature requests: https://github.com/rstudio/gt/issues. Feature requests are tagged as Enhancements and are usually successfully implemented.
report_archive_justification: The issue tracker at https://github.com/rstudio/gt/issues has the complete archive of all the reports and responses. It is easily searchable.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Vulnerabilities fall under bugs for this project. The place to report them is https://github.com/rstudio/gt/issues, and the contact information of the maintainer is available in https://github.com/rstudio/gt/blob/master/DESCRIPTION.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: The contact information of the maintainer is at https://github.com/rstudio/gt/blob/master/DESCRIPTION.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: All responses to issues are considerably faster than 14 days. Please refer to the discussion logs at https://github.com/rstudio/gt/issues.
build_justification: Using the instructions available at https://gt.rstudio.com/#installation (under "...install the development version"), users can install the package from source.
build_common_tools_justification: See the instructions available at https://gt.rstudio.com/#installation. The two most common tools for installing R packages (`install.packages()` and `devtools::install_github()`) can be used for gt.
build_floss_tools_justification: The gt package only requires formally released R packages on CRAN http://cran.r-project.org/ to install.
test_invocation_justification: The tests are in the standard format for R packages. Using the testthat package (http://github.com/r-lib/testthat), it is easy to run the tests. Standard R package quality checks run these tests, as do `testthat::test_package()` and `devtools::test()`. This is the de facto standard for R packages.
test_most_justification: The tests run by testthat::test_package()/devtools::test() under the default settings run nearly every line of code in the package. The test results are sent to a 3rd party service for reporting on code coverage, a metric that is taken very seriously for this project.
test_policy_justification: New tests for the functionality are added to the existing unit test suite, and these tests are checked with continuous integration (GitHub Actions) in a pull request before being merged into the project.
tests_are_added_justification: Evidence for the testing policy is available in the pull requests page (https://github.com/rstudio/gt/pulls) and also in the commit history (https://github.com/rstudio/gt/commits/master).
tests_documented_added_justification: In the pull request instructions (https://github.com/rstudio/gt/blob/master/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md), there is a checklist item that expresses the requirement for new tests to be added with the proposed changes.
warnings_justification: The lintr package https://github.com/jimhester/lintr is used to provide guidance on code quality during the development process.
warnings_fixed_justification: A GitHub Actions workflow can effectively detect warnings during installation and testing. Notifications are sent to the maintainer's email and to the respective badge shown in the project repository README.md.
warnings_strict_justification: The GitHub Actions workflow for checking the package (with R CMD check) is configured to fail if any warnings are detected.
know_secure_design_justification: The codebase almost entirely consists of functions. These are uncomplicated and generally divided between exported and non-exported functions. All exported functions (i.e., user-side) are highly documented. The current maintainer has written nearly all functions entirely, and any incoming contributions are reviewed line-by-line via PRs. With this process in place, attempts to vandalize the code and make it less secure can be easily detected.
know_common_errors_justification: The maintainer of gt is experienced in programming in R, the language of the implementation. Those errors that lead to vulnerabilities in R packages can be easily recognized by the maintainer. That said, security vulnerabilities are likely to come from other components that gt uses (other R packages as dependencies). To circumvent this, there is a policy to only use packages that the maintainer trusts (based on the reputations of the package developers and other factors), and to periodically review the dependency packages for indications of possible security vulnerabilities.
crypto_published_justification: This is out of scope for gt and other R packages that do not explicitly focus on privacy and security.

static_analysis_justification: The lintr package (https://github.com/jimhester/lintr) is used by developers of this project. If any lints are found, the maintainer is required to make the necessary changes such that linting  successfully passes.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: The lintr package (https://github.com/jimhester/lintr) is used by developers of this project. If any lints are found, the maintainer is required to make the necessary changes such that linting  successfully passes. This tool can easily reveal common vulnerabilities in the codebase.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: All lints from lintr are quickly addressed after they are discovered.
static_analysis_often_justification: All linting from lintr is performed regularly and is part of the development process.
dynamic_analysis_justification: All linting from lintr is performed regularly and is part of the development process. This process includes releases of the software.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: The gt package is entirely implemented in R and as such it does not use any memory-unsafe language.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Dynamic analysis is not required for gt. This is true for all R packages that are implemented entirely in R (without uses of C, C++, etc.).
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: Dynamic analysis is not required for gt. This is true for all R packages that are implemented entirely in R (without uses of C, C++, etc.). If there are related issues, they are solved soon after their reporting (see https://github.com/rstudio/gt/issues).
crypto_weaknesses_justification: This is out of scope for gt and other R packages that do not explicitly focus on privacy and security.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The gt package uses GitHub Actions to run R CMD check (a comprehensive set of tests for the package) with each commit and pull request. Users can verify the status of recently run checks by inspecting the badge on the project README. Merging doesn't occur unless all CI checks pass.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: https://github.com/rstudio/gt is a public repository. Owing to that, there are no limitations on the access to the package and its source code

name: Perseo Complex Event Processing
description: Perseo is an Esper-based Complex Event Processing (CEP) software designed to be fully NGSI-v2-compliant. It uses NGSI-v2 as the communication protocol for events, and thus, Perseo is able to seamless and jointly work with context brokers. The context broker tested with Perseo and officially supported is Orion Context Broker.
sites_https_justification: The project website and repo use GitHub, which supports HTTPS using TLS. There's no separate download URL (use git to download from the repo).
interact_justification: Information described in the following document: https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/blob/master/docs/developer/contributing.md
contribution_justification:
Process described in the following document:
https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/blob/master/docs/developer/contributing.md
contribution_requirements_justification:
Requirements described in the following document
https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/blob/master/docs/developer/contributing.md
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/blob/master/LICENSE
floss_license_justification: The AGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The AGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: The directory "docs" contains most documentation at https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/tree/master/docs
documentation_interface_justification: Its interface is defined under API directory: https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/tree/master/docs/API
repo_public_justification: It uses git, URL is <https:/github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe
repo_track_justification: Uses git to track this. Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Interim versions are put on git, not just final versions.
repo_distributed_justification: Uses git. Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: The primary development team uses git commit records to identify releases. Regular umbrella releases aligned with the FIWARE Foundation.
version_tags_justification: Full releases are tagged using 'git tag'.
release_notes_justification: Release notes are included as part of the release in github (for example: https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/releases/tag/1.20.0). In addition, a CHANGES_NEXT_RELEASE file is hold in top directory in master branch (https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/blob/master/CHANGES_NEXT_RELEASE) with the delta of changes for the next release.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There have been no publicly known vulnerabilities
report_process_justification:
Yes, GitHub issue tracker. The process is described on the following link: 
https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/blob/master/docs/developer/contributing.md
report_responses_justification:
Yes. This is a requirement for membership of the FIWARE Foundation Catalogue
https://www.fiware.org/developers/catalogue/
enhancement_responses_justification: The project has been responding to most enhancement requests.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No external reports so far, so this is vacuously true.
build_justification: The software is written using JavaScript and their implementations run directly on the source code.
build_common_tools_justification: Note that an npm package is provided to enable others to quickly recreate a development environment.
test_justification:
Yes, it includes a test suite based on Mocha
https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/blob/master/docs/developer/development.md#testing
test_invocation_justification: Yes. "npm test" invokes the automated test suite. This is documented in https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/blob/master/docs/developer/development.md#testing
test_most_justification: Met. Currently coverage of the codebase is well over 80%. More info here: https://coveralls.io/github/telefonicaid/perseo-fe?branch=master
test_policy_justification:
Yes. The CONTRIBUTING file at https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/blob/master/docs/developer/contributing.md
says, "For any new feature added, unit tests must be provided, following the example of the ones already created."
tests_are_added_justification: Tests are added as new functionality is added. This is verified during the pull request code review, ensuring that proper tests are included in the pull request before merging it.
tests_documented_added_justification:
Yes, at the contribution policies at 
https://github.com/telefonicaid/perseo-fe/blob/master/docs/developer/contributing.md
‚ÄúRemember to check both the linters and the tests before creating the Pull Request‚Äù
warnings_justification:
The set of tools used for examining code quality are listed in CONTRIBUTING.md.
The project uses eslint is used to look for problems in Javascript. The markdown documentation is scanned with remark and textlint. Docker files are scanned with Hadolint.
warnings_fixed_justification: In general warnings are addressed. In some cases warnings are disabled for specific cases.
warnings_strict_justification: The settings for the warning tools are generally fairly strict.
know_secure_design_justification: The FIWARE Perseo development team has developers who know how to design secure software
know_common_errors_justification: The FIWARE Perseo development team has developers who know how to design secure software
crypto_published_justification:
This application is a microservice which delegates security to other components such as Keyrock or Keyrock. These security components use bcrypt to store salted hashed iterated passwords, and https+standard crypto protocols to communicate with users.

Also, this software use the standard nodeJS libraries (express as a web server and requests as a client) to implement https functionalities.
crypto_call_justification: This software relies on well-known libraries implementing cryptographic.
crypto_floss_justification:
The aforementioned libraries use a FLOSS license. 
https://github.com/expressjs/express/blob/master/LICENSE
https://github.com/request/request/blob/master/LICENSE
crypto_keylength_justification: Cryptographic libraries used by this application and/or the other microservices to which it interacts (Keyrock or Keystone) allow the usage of such minimum key lengths.
crypto_working_justification: FIWARE Perseo doesn‚Äôt use any broken cryptographic algorithm.
crypto_pfs_justification: Nothing in the code inhibits or prevents the use of PFS; that is a property of the website's web server.
crypto_random_justification: Cryptographic libraries used by FIWARE Perseo and/or the other microservices to which it interacts (Keyrock or Keystone) use randomized mechanisms.
delivery_mitm_justification: This microservice delegates HTTPS by using a reverse proxy or the load balancer.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Perseo does not use cryptographic hashes in any HTTP unsecure endpoint.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No such vulnerabilities at this time.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: No such vulnerabilities at this time.
static_analysis_justification: The project uses eslint (https://eslint.org/) for this purpose. This analysis tool is used as part of the default test process used in local development, as well as the continuous integration server
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: eslint specifically looks for common vulnerabilities in JavaScript applications.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: This is vacuously true, since we've had no reports of vulnerabilities that apply to a deployed system.
static_analysis_often_justification: All commits to GitHub are run through Github Actions, which performs a number of static analysis checks
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Not applicable, software written using Javascript
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Instead of embedding run-time assertions, there are many external tests with assertions that are checked during automated testing.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: No issues were found by dynamic analysis.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: FIWARE Perseo doesn‚Äôt depend on cryptographic algorithms with known vulnerabilities.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Code implements continuous integration based in GitActions. Each time a new pull request is created, the continuous integration system runs the test on it and it is ready to merge only when all tests pass ok. If a problem is found, feedback is provided via GitHub. In addition, several badges on top of the master README.md of the project provide information about the build status in the master branch.
discussion_justification: GitHub issue tracker and pull requests support discussion
no_leaked_credentials_justification: No valid private credentials appears in public repositories. When some usernames and/or passwords needs to be used, it is never included in repositories and proper mechanism (e.g. Docker secrets) are used at software building and deployment time.
english_justification: All documentation is in English, and the project accepts bug reports and comments in English.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.

release_notes_justification:
PostgREST keeps a Changelog at <https://github.com/PostgREST/postgrest/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md>.
More detailed release notes are available at <https://postgrest.org/en/stable/index.html#release-notes>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There have been no CVEs, so far.
report_tracker_justification: PostgREST uses the GitHub issue tracker: <https://github.com/PostgREST/postgrest/issues>
report_process_justification: PostgREST uses the GitHub issue tracker: <https://github.com/PostgREST/postgrest/issues>
report_responses_justification:
Last checked on 2022-02-03.
Within the last 12 months 155 issues have been created, of which 30 were bug reports, all of which have been acknowledged.
enhancement_responses_justification:
Last checked on 2022-02-03.
Within the last 12 months 155 issues have been created, of which 32 were enhancement requests. Except for 3, all of them have been acknowledged.
report_archive_justification:
Issues are kept in the issue tracker: <https://github.com/PostgREST/postgrest/issues>
Further discussion is happening at GitHub discussions: <https://github.com/PostgREST/postgrest/discussions>
build_justification: The build system is described at <https://github.com/PostgREST/postgrest/tree/main/nix>.
build_common_tools_justification: The code is built with cabal or stack, both of which are common for Haskell.
test_justification: All tests are run in CI and can be run locally via nix as documented here: <https://github.com/PostgREST/postgrest/tree/main/nix>
test_invocation_justification:
The tests need a PostgreSQL database to run, which is automatically setup when using our nix-based tooling.

Running the tests with cabal or stack directly would miss that database.
test_policy_justification: PostgREST uses codecov to measure code coverage across changed lines in pull requests.
tests_are_added_justification: PostgREST uses codecov to measure code coverage across changed lines in pull requests.
warnings_fixed_justification: GHC is run with "-Werror". Building will fail with warnings.
warnings_strict_justification: GHC is run with "-Werror". Building will fail with warnings.
crypto_published_justification: PostgREST uses JSON Web Tokens which are described in RFC 7519: <https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7519>
crypto_call_justification:
PostgREST uses jose, a haskell implementation of JWT: <https://hackage.haskell.org/package/jose>)

jose: JSON Object Signing and Encryption (JOSE) and JSON Web Token (JWT) library
crypto_floss_justification: jose is released with an Apache-2.0 license
crypto_keylength_justification: HS256 uses a minimum of 256 bits for keys as required by the RFC spec.
crypto_password_storage_justification: Users have to implement their own code, our documentation (<https://postgrest.org/en/stable/auth.html#sql-user-management> ) gives an example for a blowfish based algorithm "bf" implemented in pgcrypto: <https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/pgcrypto.html>
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: None of the static code analyzers has those features available, as far as we know.
static_analysis_often_justification: CI runs those tools on every commit / PR.
dynamic_analysis_justification: PostgREST's CI runs loadtests based on vegeta (<https://github.com/tsenart/vegeta>) and some basic memory consumption tests to avoid memory leaks.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Haskell is memory-safe and CPP preprocessing is only used for code inclusion / exclusion via makros. No actual C/C++ code is written.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: PostgREST implements CI based on GitHub Actions: <https://github.com/PostgREST/postgrest/actions>
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

// No release notes file found.

This Javascript library has no dependencies on other libraries.

Dev dependencies are only required for collaborators who choose to work on the repository code.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: To be addressed in due course. I haven't yet written a 'contributions and security page' for the library's website, or a CONTRIBUTIONS.md or SECURITY.md file for the library's repo.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: To be addressed in due course. I haven't yet written a 'contributions and security page' for the library's website, or a CONTRIBUTIONS.md or SECURITY.md file for the library's repo.

test_justification: Details for running an automated test (for the TypeScript .d.ts file) are included in the repo's README.md file
test_most_justification: The library aims to make HTML <canvas> elements more responsive, and more accessible. This includes canvas-based animations. Most testing is conducted manually, through visual review of a suite of Demo pages covering (almost) the entire functionality of the library. Each Demo page includes details about the test, and the expected outcomes to be checked against. This is fully explained in the website's Demo Tests page - https://scrawl-v8.rikweb.org.uk/demonstrations
test_policy_justification: New functionality added to the library must be accompanied by a Demo file allowing people to visually inspect the intended output of that functionality - https://scrawl-v8.rikweb.org.uk/demonstrations
tests_are_added_justification:
Recent Demos added to the Demos suite:
- A gradients stress test Demo, to assess the impact on page performance of applying complex gradients to multiple graphical entitys - https://scrawl-v8.rikweb.org.uk/demo/canvas-061.html
- A CSS color space Demo, to test that color strings supplied in permitted formats correctly display in a <canvas> element - https://scrawl-v8.rikweb.org.uk/demo/canvas-059.html
- A Demo to explore and test new functionality for applying a reduced-palette filter (including dithering) to an image - https://scrawl-v8.rikweb.org.uk/demo/filters-027.html
tests_documented_added_justification: I haven't yet added a CONTRIBUTIONS.md file to the repo
